posts.author: WhiZard
posts.content:
Speed Caster (Sorc 36/Monk 3/Pal 1)
This build features an added benefit to the exalted sorceress template- that is, fast speed. The normal 1.5 * base speed cap to movement speed is overridden by monk speed (at monk 3) and stacking of speed bonuses occur as follows: Initial Speed = 1.00(base speed) + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.10. Cast Mass Haste for 1.5 * Initial Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.1 + 0.1 = 1.75. Cast expeditious retreat for 1.5 * Mass Haste Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.75 + 0.1 = 2.725. That speed can outrun any natural monk (monk 39 moves at 2.30), giving the sorcerer a huge edge in casting and running without getting caught. If both spells are extended you can have 7 full turns at this fantastic speed, which is probably enough time to allow you to unleash your spell arsenal.
What does fast speed give?
Improved herding skills. See that mob of scattered melee enemies all moving the same speed? Simply circle around the mob again and again and watch it cluster together. When it becomes a compact group unleash your area of effect spells. (Oh, and since your hasted you cast in half the usual time, so while herding you can still cast spells without being attacked).
Run past your enemies to the advantageous terrain. See that cliff? The way up is far away but you can make it there and run back on top of the cliff, leaving your enemies unable to determine which way to go to reach you.
Avoid the bosses. Those nasty monsters that can dish out hundreds of damage with their smite (or whatever power) seem a lot less threatening if they cannot attack before collapsing.
Human, Lawful Good
PvM/PvP 1-40 (Does especially well in low to medium magic environments)
Strength 10
Dexterity 8
Constitution 14
Wisdom 8
Intelligence 14
Charisma 18 (38)

Hitpoints: 298(max roll), 227.5(average roll)
Skillpoints: 227
Saving throws: Fortitude 36, Reflex 31, Will 36
BAB: 20
AB: 22/17 (naked, unbuffed)
AC: 17 (naked, unbuffed)

Skills:
Concentration 43 (45)
Discipline 42 (42)
Lore 17 (19)
Persuade 42 (56)
Spellcraft 43 (45)
Tumble 40 (39)

This build features an added benefit to the exalted sorceress template- that is, fast speed. The normal 1.5 * base speed cap to movement speed is overridden by monk speed (at monk 3) and stacking of speed bonuses occur as follows: Initial Speed = 1.00(base speed) + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.10. Cast Mass Haste for 1.5 * Initial Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.1 + 0.1 = 1.75. Cast expeditious retreat for 1.5 * Mass Haste Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.75 + 0.1 = 2.725.
Questions about speed, WhiZard...

Does the stacking occur even with a permahaste item equipped? (I assume the perma effect would just get ignored while the spells are active.)

Mass Haste doesn't cancel the effects of Expeditious Retreat. Haste does. Is this a bug? If not, what is the reason for the difference?

Would more monk levels increase the end speed higher than the 2.725? If so, is there a cap?

posts.author: WhiZard
posts.content:
HipMaestro wrote:
WhiZard wrote:Speed Caster (Sorc 35/Monk 3/Pal 2)
This build features an added benefit to the exalted sorceress template- that is, fast speed. The normal 1.5 * base speed cap to movement speed is overridden by monk speed (at monk 3) and stacking of speed bonuses occur as follows: Initial Speed = 1.00(base speed) + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.10. Cast Mass Haste for 1.5 * Initial Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.1 + 0.1 = 1.75. Cast expeditious retreat for 1.5 * Mass Haste Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.75 + 0.1 = 2.725.
Questions about speed, WhiZard...

Does the stacking occur even with a permahaste item equipped? (I assume the perma effect would just get ignored while the spells are active.)

Mass Haste doesn't cancel the effects of Expeditious Retreat. Haste does. Is this a bug? If not, what is the reason for the difference?

Would more monk levels increase the end speed higher than the 2.725? If so, is there a cap?
Here's the full description, the formative parts of which can be found in the talk page of the monk article at the NWN wiki.

Monk speed is an additive bonus reflecting a percentage of the base speed (normal speed with or without encumbrance, stealth/detect mode, running/walking).
Speed increases and decreases (as can be found with haste, slow, and expeditious retreat) are multiplicative bonuses that base their increase/decrease on the current speed.
--
When a speed increase/decrease is added a recursive formulation follows multiplying first and then re-adding the monk bonus.
When a speed increase/decrease is removed then the speed is recalculated multiplying first and then adding the monk bonus once thereafter.
--
The spells haste, expeditious retreat, and blinding speed try to be mutual exclusive, thus their scripts do not allow for stacking.
--
The cap for one with monk speed is (3.0 + monk speed bonus) * base speed. Without monk speed the cap is 1.5 * base speed.

--
--
Thus for direct answers.

Perma-haste does stack with expeditious (though without monk speed either of the two already reaches the cap). Just remember to unequip and reequip the perma-haste item whenever you lose a speed affecting effect (this causes the monk speed to be considered multiple times).

A monk 6 build with mass haste and expeditious retreat has pretty much reached full potential ((1.2 * 1.5) + 0.2) * 1.5 + 0.2) = 3.2 which is the cap (3.0 + 0.2) for a level 6 monk. After that every three monk levels only increases the speed by 0.1 because of the cap. Though every 3 levels of monk means 6 less rounds of extended expeditious retreat and extended mass haste.

posts.author: Shia_Luck
posts.content:
Hi darktooth :)

I like that you have got spell penetration in there (looking back at Whizzard's, I now wonder why blindfight is there, I was too amazed at the speed boost to notice anything else I guess!).

Monk is taken on lvl16 to get 15 tumble. The monk lvl is better at 17 and get 20 tumble for +1 AC while levelling, imho. Is there a reason you have gone for listen? You shouldn't need to be afraid of sneaks, but that depends on spell choice too I guess. Similarly, if you don't want persuade, and listen could be superfluous, you could drop the starting INT by 2. You don't have any feats needing INT13. It'd get you +1AC if put into DEX and with this character you aren't going to get caught flat footed and lose it. Although having said that, discipline is not required either. There's a potential 4 starting attribute points to be played with?

S35/M4/P1 gives you the same bonus sorc feats, but it'd mean you'd be able to make another tumble dump and get your speed boost as early as lvl 21 (well, 23 to get all your 9th lvl spells) which would make it more playable until lvl 40. Just a thought.

Have fun :)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'm wondering - as a caster-ignoramus - whether Toughness or Blind Fight would be preferable? Also, with 4 levels in Monk, would it make sense to take those levels at 2, 17, 22 and 37? And I'd always try to have at least one perception skill, and with Monk it should be Listen. Still, dropping Discipline makes sense, so taking INT down by 2 points for DEX remains a good idea.

(Of course, as a non-caster I fully expect to be put in a bag and dropped in a river here)

Cheers

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
Shia_Luck wrote: ...you could drop the starting INT by 2. You don't have any feats needing INT13. It'd get you +1AC if put into DEX and with this character you aren't going to get caught flat footed and lose it...
Brilliant feedback..if I'm going for the alternative, this is how I'll distribute the available skill points: Concentration 43(45), Heal 17(16), Listen 42(41), Spellcraft 39(40), Tumble 40(39). I woudn't go for the extra monk lvl though, as I want its spells to be difficult to resist. That's also why I got greater spell penetration.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
It looks good darktooth!

I have experience with this kind of character from playing my Evil Speed Caster. I only have minor tweaks to suggest for your take on this:
My personal preference would be to take Silent spell as well for all those spells you want to cast from one slot higher, that cannot be extended. I would drop Greater penetration for that.
If you have too many skills, and I think you do, you can always drop Intelligence to 10 and start with Constitution 16 for better hitpoints.
If you really plan on running, AC is not that important, and Tumble can stop at 15, just enough to avoid attacks of opportunity.
If the True seeing spell works normally, listen is a good skill to supplement it with. If the TS spell is nerfed to only add a bonus to Spot, I would take the Spot skill and improve it with the spell.

posts.author: Shia_Luck
posts.content:
I agree Stag, a character should always have one perception skill, however, sorc may be the exception.(It depends on environment as always). With this levelling you aren't getting a boost to that until lvl16/17. However, before then, you have enough lvl2 and 3 spell slots to keep see invisibility up all day long if you are worried about sneaks attacking you outside of combat. In combat you will have see invis and ultravision or true seeing up anyway. So I'd say it's mostly superfluous, environment dependent. (Blind fight is only useful if you want to try to hit something (afaik) and this character is running from melee.). However, those extra 2 points of starting stats are less easy to fill in somewhere useful. Now we have dropped discipline it may not help anyway. (I'll need to look again at a not ridiculously late hour, *grin*)

Fair enough Darktooth. The 4th monk only makes it earlier for the speed boost really. If it's for a PW its purely down to choice ofc but I always think it's a shame to have to play it as a pure sorc/whatever until lvl37+. (I know that's not the point of this guild, but I think it's worth a mention) Having played a few speedy sorceressesesses (What? it's a hard word to stop spelling!) It's the lvl15+ to UntilYouGetEpicSpells that it really shines, so I'd go for 17 to get the speed boost. 12 to get the magic tumble number 15, and 7 as the first. your spell pen feats will cover the shortfall and you only lose 1 caster lvl. But that's all levelling thought, not the final character. Oh! If you have decuided to drop discipline then the final monk can be 37 now, not 39. it's only for tumble now, no?

Have fun :)

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
The additional 2 points in listen may give the final build a slight advantage, if only one is not so concerned with the lower AC at lvl 37-38. That said, see invisibility and ultravision are still indispensable. Btw, I edited my first post to include list of spells. Leveling is revised according to some of your suggestions.

@Mick Dagger : I read your post a bit late. Great feedback!

Update: Silent Spell included in my first post. I just need more time to rethink and maybe make more changes.

@Mick Dagger : If Constitution is very important, then I figure Endurance spell should also be in the spellbook. Which of the spells in lvl 2 should be replaced? I didn't include True Seeing so See Invisibility and Ultravision should stay. Also, Spot is not a class skill for any of the 3 classes of this build that's why I chose Listen.

...after much thinking, the only way I see it, is to make sure the build always has a permahaste item equipped, then substitute Mass Haste for True Seeing. Invisibility and Ultravision can now be swapped with Endurance and another useful spell, like Death Armor.

...my pondering now brings me to the next question, and forgive my ignorance. In PWs where True Seeing is nerfed, how much does it add to Spot and Listen?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
darktooth wrote: @Mick Dagger : I read your post a bit late. Great feedback!
Thanks! First I only wrote "It looks good".  Later I edited it and added my comments.

darktooth wrote: @Mick Dagger : If Constitution is very important, then I figure Endurance spell should also be in the spellbook. Which of the spells in lvl 2 should be replaced? I didn't include True Seeing so See Invisibility and Ultravision should stay. Also, Spot is not a class skill for any of the 3 classes of this build that's why I chose Listen.

...after much thinking, the only way I see it, is to make sure the build always has a permahaste item equipped, then substitute Mass Haste for True Seeing. Invisibility and Ultravision can now be swapped with Endurance and another useful spell, like Death Armor.

...my pondering now brings me to the next question, and forgive my ignorance. In PWs where True Seeing is nerfed, how much does it add to Spot and Listen?
Sorcerers and Wizards are low on hitpoints with their 1d4 hit die. Constitution is not a major priority, that is Charisma, but it adds  to the hit point pool and makes life a little bit easier. It doesn't hurt with a slightly better fort save either. An empowered Endurance also gives a good boost.
A permahaste item and Expeditious retreat should do the trick and get you running like mad, and give you that extra action per round that Haste provides. You can stack several castings of Expeditious retreat for more speed if you feel you need it.
Normally I prefer Listen over Spot, except for my snipers and sneakers, where I want the hidden targets to appear in the line of sight. The TS spell will normally make things visible for a Sorcerer.
Picking spells is important and sometimes challenging. You want to be able to handle different challenges, and the spells you pick will also reflect your spell focus and your preferred tactics. What low level spells to pick also depends on your character level. When you first get level 3 spells, Fireball is very strong. Later in the game you rather want Flame arrow because it becomes a much better spell.
As for spell changes, I recommend that you read the web pages of the PW you want to try. The spell changes are often announced somewhere in the Forum pages together with other custom changes.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: I edited my first post again. I’d appreciate any feedback.

posts.author: Shia_Luck
posts.content:
I am blind! Well spotted @Mick Dagger. Yip the extra starting points are better in CON. +1 CON on an item and s/he can survive two maxed IGMS now.

Onto the edit: Well if TS is nerfed I'd go back to ultra and see invis and drop Bull's Strength and Melf's arrow. I like Melf's while levelling as at times it can break enemy caster concentration, but it's less likely at lvl40. I'd also drop something from lvl4 (ILMS probably, you have 3 levels worth of IGMS as it is) for improved invisibility as it gives better concealment than Displacement for longer. So now there's a lvl3 slot open. I wouldn't worry about filling it right now tho. It's good to have slots free that you can fill depending on environment. Something like Stinking Cloud might work well to herd and keep them in one place while you Horrid Wilt them or to irritate enemy archers.  I'd like to see Lesser Spell Mantle at lvl5 as it will stack with Spell Mantle and covers you while recasting both mantles when they start to fail. (You will see one fail and at that point I finish my current spell and then recast both mantles because you know the next incoming spell will bring down the 2nd mantle.) I'd drop Bigby's Interposing probably. You still have a bigby available and interposing is the least useful of all of them. With the Lesser Mind Blank and Shadow Shield you put it that seems to have all the bases covered.

S/he looks great now! Have fun :)

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
@Shia_Luck : Yes, i'll take Lesser Spell Mantle for that reason
@Mick Dagger : fireball first then replace with flame arrow at sorc lvl 12

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
darktooth wrote: @Mick Dagger : fireball first then replace with flame arrow at sorc lvl 12
This was only meant as a single example of how spell choices on different spell levels may change with increasing caster levels.
Fireball is an area spell and has different uses then flame arrow that is a single target spell.  I replace fireball with firebrand, but don't discard fireball before I can meta firebrand.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: So far, the few other instances when I changed spells at higher levels were when I replaced see invisibility and ultravision with TS, and greater spell breach with mordenkainen’s disjunction. Anyway, thank you for that tidbit.

posts.author: Horri
posts.content:
Very interesting builds thank you Whizard and darktooth.
I have a question. If planning to use this on an online PW server, wouldn't it be risky not to have greater spell penetration, as it is hard to know beforehand if your spells will be resisted by the more high level enemies? It would be a bummer to go to 40 to find out that so I was wondering is it better to be safe and have GSP.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: Even with epic spell penetration, its spells may still not work against a lvl 40 monk with spell resistance feats, so a spell caster cannot really be safe. This is also why this spell caster build is my favorite, because it is most capable of avoiding dire situations.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Ah, those SR>60 monks...You are better off using your damage shields against them anyway, although, in a real-time game such as Neverwinter Nights, reflexes are almost as important as your tactical ability, so it can go either way.

posts.author: Shia_Luck
posts.content:
SR Monks are a pain. Definitly a good argument for damage shields (My least favourite spells cos they feel so lame, lol) Think sneaky tho. Grease still works after the first round for example.

Have fun :)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
For a great SR monk (and, as I'm sure you'll appreciate, I fall very heavily on the side of the monk over the spell-chucker) - and discussions around such - I'd refer you to Valerfor's Grand Master of Flowers (Monk 40), which surfaces in Campgod's Looking for a Mage Killer thread on page 14 of the Unfinished Builds/Build Requests sub-forum. I would give a link here, but it doesn't seem to want to play with me atm, sorry. It's a lovely build to play, and it's always fun feeding casters their asses!

Cheers

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: Edited my first post to show spellbook at lvl 40

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The best is the Deadly Nightshade.

This Monk/SD/Ass has high enough SR to resist almost everything a caster can throw at you...and has UMD.

Yeah, that little Lesser Breach brother just blows the living FUCK off of damage shields!

This build makes everyone shiver, and shake...because it is death incarnate.  Knock'em down, after blowing off their pathetic protections!  Watch them cry in horror as spell after spell just slides right off!  Throw up some spell mantles to make them even more terrified!  Then rip them apart with your fists.

Whether Cleric, or Fighter, or whatever - you win. 

Now, you may be in an environment where magic is at a very high level (+20 or whatever) or one that has changed things away from vanilla - this may affect things accordingly, so it is always a word to the wise to first take into account the environment before doing your build.

Please be aware that the Deadly Nightshade does make use of Circle Kick.  Some may not like this, but my findings have been glowingly positive (meaning I have never dirtnapped because of it).

Greater Ruin could be your downfall - invest heavily in Con in such an environment.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: This is still my favorite build. I made changes to my first post again specifically on the spells this character has at lvl 40. Its spellbook is now almost identical to the original Exalted Sorceress template.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
Notes on spell selection (refer to page 2 of this thread):
 
The tweaked build will have little or no option to melee even at the start, therefore will have a harder time progressing at lower levels. However, high saves will make it formidable against spell casters. Obtaining equipment granting perma haste and damage reduction early offers great advantage. The list of spells in my first post almost reflects the order that the spells were selected, with a few switches that I will attempt to detail:
 
Fireball is acquired as soon as it becomes attainable.
ILMS is selected after Evard’s and Ice Storm, but is discarded at the time when IGMS is picked up.
When  a lvl 7 spell slot becomes available, Fireball is ditched for Flame Arrow. 
Bigby 7, 8 and 9 are acquired, with higher level spell replacing the former, but Bigby 6 is retained
Another third lvl 7 spell is selected (e.g Mordenkainen’s Sword) before changing it to Spell Mantle once the later can be empowered.
Upon getting Mordenkainen’s Disjunction, Greater Spell Breach is replaced by True Seeing, which in turn is later swapped for Mass Haste (preferably upon reaching lvl 38 of the build, or soon after gaining equipment with True Seeing property, whichever you choose.)
 
Further suggestions are welcome.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I would sacrifice 1 level of Sorc for Pally 2.

Immunity to fear is soooo nice!

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: Pally 2 would be a desirable option if I knew of fear spells/effects without save. Otherwise, I don’t see it being more advantageous.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Pally 2 would be a desirable option if I knew of fear spells/effects without save. Otherwise, I don’t see it being more advantageous.
Well, first of all there are Breaches/Mord's to be wary of. 

Second, assuming one is using an item with an immunity to fear property, one can instead put something else there, something more useful.

However, if your environment has good stuff with such on it, by all means use them.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I think the fear immunity suggestion is nice. Depends on the environment / equipment / personal preference which is optimal for the player.
I like darktooth's spell list! 

In terms of spells for PvM I would add:
- Grease at level 1, if I have access to knockdown immunity
- Darkness and (empowered) endurance at level 2
- Stinking cloud and prot v elements at level 3
- Mestil's Acid Sheath at level 5
- Bigby's 7 at level 7 for knockdown immune meleers (who Bigby's 6 won't work on)

Dropping Negative energy burst, Invisibility, Negative energy burst, displacement, Energy buffer and spell mantle.

True seeing would be nice too but extended mass haste is needed to get the most out of the speed caster, can sometimes come from items (Gem of Seeing). 

All personal preference of course! I like to spam a few AoE crowd control spells as well. Those archers can't shoot me, if they can't see through the darkness! :) And I can stand in the stinky cloud if I cast prot v good on myself! :) Oh and an extended 72 round CL 36 (1d6+72 acid / hit) Mestil's Acid Sheath! Wow! Although with all the toys at one's disposal, so many of the features never get used!

In terms of the monk levels, I would get Sorc 20 then rush Monk 1-2-3. In the dispel/mord spamming environment that Web and I torture ourselves in (WoG), even getting Sorc 24 before the first Monk level might be attractive. Getting those faster higher sorc levels makes playing easier I've found than getting monk stuff, when I've played a sorc/speed caster myself. I can understand the late monk level however to try to near max listen, but its nice to get the features earlier rather than later.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
@Orion: Your suggestion made me deliberate about Bigby's and edit my last post. So I will take Bigby 7 and consider replacing it with a higher level Bigby when there are lvl 8 and 9 spell slots open. Bigby 9 could replace Time Stop or Wail of the Banshee, whichever is viable.

I would take Monk 1 early just for Evasion and to avoid attacks of opportunity.

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote:But the answer to the 2xER vs ER+Mass Haste, I do not really know if they are in fact that same speed.

I rather suspect that they are. 

It should be relatively easy to test imo.  Just create an area of whatever size in the Toolset, then put your Caster/Monk in it with the appropriate spells, and stopwatch the times.
Thanks, Web! It's a really interesting question, and something worth testing, because, while the ExpRet description in the Wiki says that "the spell has no effect if the character is already hasted", the Haste spell description does not have the corresponding note for ExpRet. In theory, that means (obviously if speed cap is removed) that casting ExpRet x2 FIRST, and THEN casting Haste should produce the same effect as casting ExpRet + Mass Haste, both speed- and casts per round-wise.

If so, considering that neither ExpRet, nor Haste belong to Enchantment school - this would mean that a speed caster CAN be an illusionist!

I will try to get to testing this in the evening - I'll report my findings - but if someome already tried this in the past, pls let me know your experience!

Cheers!

Отправлено с моего SM-G970F через Tapatalk

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
calespurmarksman wrote: while the ExpRet description in the Wiki says that "the spell has no effect if the character is already hasted", the Haste spell description does not have the corresponding note for ExpRet.
Strike that - here's what the Wiki says:"This spell will displace a single instance of each of expeditious retreat, mass haste, and blinding speed, provided those spells had been cast by the caster of haste."

The key here is that it displaces a SINGLE instance of ER! So it seems the theory doesn't contradict the Wiki at least....


Отправлено с моего SM-G970F через Tapatalk

posts.content:
It is only the Haste spell - not Haste from, say, an item (like Boots of Speed).

Note that Mass Haste is a different spell than Haste.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

Sure, Mass Haste is a known way of reaching the Monk speed cap, but I just want to explore whether its possible with onle ER and Haste (spell), not Mass Haste, available, as this would allow for a wizard to specialize in a spell school and get a lot of extra spell slots.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If I understood your post correctly, Haste cast as a spell gave different results depending on the order in which the spells were cast.
A permanent item property differs from a cast spell in several ways. It could be worth testing the way you did with the spell. Is there a difference if you equip the item first, in between or last? Do you get the same speed as you did with the cast spell? etc.

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote:If I understood your post correctly, Haste cast as a spell gave different results depending on the order in which the spells were cast.
A permanent item property differs from a cast spell in several ways. It could be worth testing the way you did with the spell. Is there a difference if you equip the item first, in between or last? Do you get the same speed as you did with the cast spell? etc.
Hm, yes -that is interesting.

Theoretically, as per the Wiki ("ER has no effect if the character is already hasted"), if you have a perma-haste item equipped, casting ER will have no effect at all. The item needs to be removed first, ER cast the required number of times, and then the item re-equipped. However, it remains to be tested whether following this order will yield the same results as a cast spell.

I'll try to test this when I get the chance, and get back to you.

Отправлено с моего SM-G970F через Tapatalk

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
The speed exploit happens because the spell scripts are poorly written. None of the spells check for item property Haste, so "Haste" below refers specifically to the spell.

Expeditious Retreat won't work if the target has any effects from the spell Haste, but will work if the target has effects from Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, or Mass Haste.

Haste will remove 1 casting of Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, Haste, Mass Haste from the target if they were cast by the caster.
If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves and then a different creature casts Haste on them then no effects will be removed, since the caster of Expeditious Retreat is not the caster of Haste.
If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves twice and then casts Haste on themselves they will only remove 1 casting of Expeditious Retreat, ending up with Expeditious Retreat and Haste.

Mass Haste has no checks in the spell script and doesn't remove any effects either.

Blinding Speed is like Haste, removing 1 casting of Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, Haste, and Mass Haste from the target if they were cast by the caster.

posts.author: calespurmarksman
posts.content:
Yunim wrote:The speed exploit happens because the spell scripts are poorly written. None of the spells check for item property Haste, so "Haste" below refers specifically to the spell.

Expeditious Retreat won't work if the target has any effects from the spell Haste, but will work if the target has effects from Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, or Mass Haste.

Haste will remove 1 casting of Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, Haste, Mass Haste from the target if they were cast by the caster.
If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves and then a different creature casts Haste on them then no effects will be removed, since the caster of Expeditious Retreat is not the caster of Haste.
If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves twice and then casts Haste on themselves they will only remove 1 casting of Expeditious Retreat, ending up with Expeditious Retreat and Haste.

Mass Haste has no checks in the spell script and doesn't remove any effects either.

Blinding Speed is like Haste, removing 1 casting of Blinding Speed, Expeditious Retreat, Haste, and Mass Haste from the target if they were cast by the caster.
Hi, Yunim! Thank you for clarifying!
Yunim wrote:The speed exploit happens because the spell scripts are poorly written. None of the spells check for item property Haste, so "Haste" below refers specifically to the spell.
Form this, it follows that is Haste is applied as item property, the result should indeed be different, with no ERs removed. Have you tested this previously?
I do recall there was a discussion some way back, that a perma-haste item needs to be removed and re-equipped after all speed increasing effects from spells have run out - do you know a reasoning for that, because I didn't quite understand this part?
Thanks!

This part is especially interesting:
Yunim wrote:If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves and then a different creature casts Haste on them then no effects will be removed, since the caster of Expeditious Retreat is not the caster of Haste.
While it does follow from the Wiki, I'm wondering whether this has been tested in a party?
Yunim wrote:If the target casts Expeditious Retreat on themselves twice and then casts Haste on themselves they will only remove 1 casting of Expeditious Retreat, ending up with Expeditious Retreat and Haste.
The results of my tests show, however, that ER+Haste is a lower speed than 2xER or ER+Mass Haste. Yunim, do you maybe know a reason for this?
I suspect, that its because Haste becomes an additive bonus if applied as a secondary effect, rather than a multiplicative, but it's interesting what the scripts say, for therein the truth layeth :)

Cheers!

Отправлено с моего SM-G970F через Tapatalk

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I've used Expeditious Retreat with permahaste items before, it does increase speed without the need for Haste (spell) / Mass Haste.

ER -> Haste results in Haste, since casting Haste removes ER.
ER -> ER -> Haste or ER -> Mass Haste or Mass Haste -> ER will all result in ER + Haste.

I might make a test module later to see how movement speed stacks.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Below is a list of results for movement speed testing.
I tested 3 builds (Wiz37/Monk1, Wiz37/Monk3, Monk35/Pal4/Rog1) over the same distance (roughly 100m).
Timing and placement was all done via scripts, the only thing I did was press "W" so the runs should be as equal as possible.
There is a small amount of variance in the times, but anything within 0.2 seconds is roughly the same time.

Wiz37/Monk1. Base Time: 24.4s. Best Time: 16.1s. Base Speed: ~4.10 m/s. Max Speed: ~6.21 m/s. Speed Increase: ~52%.
Wiz37/Monk3. Base Time: 22.0s. Best Time: 7.9s. Base Speed: ~4.55 m/s. Max Speed: ~12.66 m/s. Speed Increase: ~178%.
Monk35/Pal4/Rog1. Base Time: 11.6s. Best Time: 5.9s. Base Speed: ~8.62 m/s. Max Speed: ~16.95 m/s. Speed Increase: ~97%.

Key:
EHaste: Effect Haste.
IHaste: Item Property Haste.
EMSD: Effect Movement Speed Decrease.
EMSI: Effect Movement Speed Increase.
SpoilerResults

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Nicely done, Yunim.

But the distance you have used is not really usable, unfortunately.

This is why I did my measurements with AREA SIZE (in my case a 32x32 area).

This is a distance that everyone can use to measure by (any area size is usable, really, but should be mentioned).

Then we can all compare results (which logically should be the same).

In your example, you say "roughly 100m" which I have really no idea how to replicate.

The way that I did it was to use the WASD keys to face the area edge, turn around with WASD, then hit W and Stopwatch simultaneously and wait until the figure hit the the other, opposite edge of the area.

I used 32x32 because it is the biggest area available.  I found out that using smaller areas did not really show the time differences in some of the testing.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Interesting work Yunim 
But it is not quite clear to me all that one can read out of the table.
Can you please explain the terms EMSD(n) and EMSI(n) more closely?
I also wonder what "Timing and placement was all done via scripts" actually means and how that applies to the test set-up.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Every tile in an area is exactly 10m x 10m, if you run horizontally/vertically across 10 tiles then you will move a distance of 100m. At each end of a 100m track I put two triggers, one that starts a timer script when entered and one that ends the timer script when entered. Timing is done automatically in-game using this script, so as long as I don't pause the game (which can mess with in-game time) it should be accurate. I use scripting to align the direction of each character, so none of them run at a different angle which could change the distance between the triggers. The only thing I do in all of these tests is press "W" which is fairly hard to mess up. I add effects and item properties using chat commands, so I can test everything I need to with any character.

EMSD(x) is EffectMovementSpeedDecrease(x), with -9999 <= x <= 99. There's probably no lower bound, but my chat commands only go as low as -9999 without alterations. A negative EMSD effect increases movement speed,
EMSI(x) is EffectMovementSpeedIncrease(x). with -9999 <= x <= 99999. There are probably no bounds, but my chat commands only handle -9999 to 99999 without alterations. A negative EMSI effect decreases movement speed. EMSI(100) to EMSI(199) is equivalent to EMSI(0) to EMSI(99).
Neither EMSD(0) nor EMSI(0) should affect movement speed, but for builds with Monk Speed they actually increase movement speed.

EHaste + EMSI(50) = EHaste + EMSI(150) = Expeditious Retreat + Blinding Speed / Haste (spell) / Mass Haste.
IHaste + EMSI(50) = IHaste + EMSI(150) = Expeditious Retreat + Haste (item property).
So there is a difference between item property Haste and effect Haste when it comes to stacking with Monk Speed.

Vanilla speed increasing effects
Rallying Cry applies an EMSI(20) effect to the target, a 20% speed increase.
Expeditious Retreat applies an EMSI(150) effect to the target which is equivalent to an EMSI(50) effect, a 50% speed increase.
Blinding Speed, Haste (spell), and Mass Haste apply a haste effect to the target.
Haste (item property) also applies haste to the target, but based on the tests it stacks differently compared to a haste effect.

Edit: I've uploaded the test module on github. [https://github.com/YunimNWN/Public_TM/b ... _Speed.zip]

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
